1. There were no records of acquisition or record of animals on hand available at the time of the inspection for the
peacock, chickens, and emus that are on the premises.
2. The record for the number of mammals on hand was not accurate. The number of fallow deer and rabbits on the
premises are higher than the number recorded and there was no acquisition information available for those additional
animals.
Per this Section of the Regulations, exhibitors shall make and maintain complete records regarding the details of the
acquisition and disposition of animals in their possession in order to account for all animal transfers and the sources of the
animals. The Licensee needs to prepare records of acquisition and a record of animals on hand for the birds, deer, and
rabbits; update the record of animals on hand so the numbers of animals is accurate; and ensure that the animal records
are kept current for all future animal acquisitions/dispositions. Correct by 12/14/23.

The rabbits are housed outdoors in a pen that has ~1 ½” x 4” rectangular spacing wire mesh buried underneath the
ground/dirt substrate floor to prevent the rabbits from digging out of the enclosure as well as the placement of wire mesh
around the trunk/roots of a large tree inside the enclosure. There are several areas in the enclosure where the wire mesh
is exposed and not covered with dirt/other substrate, and some of the exposed wire mesh is no longer secured so the
mesh is sticking upwards in the pen. The exposed/unsecured wire mesh poses a risk of injury to the rabbits from
entrapment of the digits/feet/legs.
Per this Section, the floors of the primary enclosures shall be constructed so as to protect the rabbits’ feet and legs from
injury. The Licensee needs to address the areas of the exposed and unsecured wire mesh in this enclosure for the health
and safety of the rabbits. Correct by 12/7/23.

The rabbits are housed outdoors in a large pen that has a ground/dirt substrate floor. Much of the surface of the
floor/ground had an excessive accumulation of fecal pellets and the majority of the flat resting surface of the large rock in
the enclosure that the rabbits get up onto was covered with fecal pellets.
Per this Section, primary enclosures shall be kept reasonably free of excreta by periodic cleaning. Accumulations of fecal
matter in primary enclosures can be a health hazard for the animals and attract pests. The accumulation of fecal pellets in
the rabbit enclosure needs to removed and the frequency of removal/cleaning the fecal matter from the rabbit enclosure
needs to be increased to minimize the amount of fecal material and for the health of the rabbits. Correct by 12/7/23.

The sole water source for the “Jacob Sheep Pen” (houses 16 sheep, 1 llama, and 1 cow) is a large plastic tub located in
the front left corner of the pen. At the time of the inspection, there was standing water directly in front of and surrounding
the tub that was at least 1-2” deep and extended at least 12" from the tub. The animals had to stand in the puddle of water
to access their source of drinking water. Exposure to this type of wet conditions can result in foot and/or hoof problems in
the animals.
Per this Section, a suitable method shall be provided to rapidly eliminate excess water and provide adequate drainage.
The drainage in this pen needs to be improved so the animals do not have to stand in water in order to access their
source of drinking water. This is important to ensure the health and comfort of the animals.

The feed trough in the “smaller sheep pen” contained uneaten grain that appeared paste-like in appearance. According to
facility personnel, it had rained 2 days prior resulting in the paste-like condition of the grain from exposure to the rain. Staff
had already serviced the sheep pen that morning prior to the inspection.
Per this Section, food receptacles if used shall be kept clean and sanitary at all times. Wet paste-like grain is no longer
palatable and should be removed from feed receptacles to keep the receptacles clean. Correct by 12/1/23.

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
Although the birds at the facility were socially housed and were provided with materials to enhance their environment, a
written plan for environmental enhancement to promote the psychological well-being of the birds still had not been
developed by the licensee.
Per this Section, exhibitors must develop, document, and follow a species-appropriate plan for environment enhancement
to promote the psychological well-being of birds. The plan must be approved by the Attending Veterinarian and must be in
accordance with currently accepted professional standards as cited in appropriate professional journals or reference
guides. At a minimum, the plan must address each of the following: social grouping, environmental enrichment, special
considerations, restraint devices, and exemptions. The Licensee needs to develop an environmental enrichment plan
appropriate for the species of birds maintained and the plan must be approved by the Attending Veterinarian.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representative.
